This then determines fx by looking at the preimage D \to \Gamma \mathcal {O}_{X} \to \mathcal {O}_{X,x}.
A locally distributed space is a pair (X,\mathcal {O}_{X}), where X is a topological space and \mathcal {O}_{X} is a sheaf of local distributive lattice on X.

A morphism f : (X,\mathcal {O}_{X}) \to (Y,\mathcal {O}_{Y}) between locally distributed spaces is a continuous function f : X \to Y, together with a local morphism f^{\sharp } : f^*\mathcal {O}_{Y} \to \mathcal {O}_{X}. Here f^{\sharp } is local iff it is t-conservative. The category of locally distributed spaces will be denoted as \mathbf {Top}_{\mathbb {D}}.

fr:title.text: Quotient of prime filters are local

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Quotient of prime filters are local

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For any filter F on a distributive lattice D: D/F is local iff F is prime; D/F is 2 iff F is maximal.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: By Proposition , the inverse image of the quotient f : D \twoheadrightarrow D/F gives a one-to-one correspondence between prime filters in D/F and prime filters containing F. This way, D/F is local iff \{1\} is prime, in which case F must be prime. The case for maximality follows from the fact that 2 is the only distributive lattice with only one prime filter.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The space \operatorname {Spec} D classifies the prime filters of D in the following sense: For any topos \mathcal {X}, we have \mathbf {Topoi}(\mathcal {X},\operatorname {Spec} D) \simeq \mathbf {DL}(D,\mathrm {Sub}_{\mathcal {X}}(1)).

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: By Proposition \operatorname {Spec} D as a frame is the coherent locale \mathrm {Idl}(D) of D. Thus we indeed have \mathbf {Topoi}(\mathcal {X},\operatorname {Spec} D) \simeq \mathbf {Frm}(\mathrm {Idl}(D),\mathrm {Sub}_{\mathcal {X}}(1)) \simeq \mathbf {DL}(D,\mathrm {Sub}_{\mathcal {X}}(1)). In particular, when \mathcal {X} is two-valued, these are prime filters of D.
